Reasonable?! Avoid talk of corruption? Putin perfected corruption...it's his most significant achievement. So your argument is that this is simply investment by Russian capitalists. The main difference is that capitalists in Japan and Germany, etc, didn't loot their treasury to make these "investments".

As far as Mr. Krugman is concerned - what year did you get awarded the Nobel prize for Economics?
In Russia, TARP funds would immediately disappear into Mayfair mansions and Swiss accounts. Goldman Sachs, despite its many sins, does not actually shoot down Dutch airliners.
Whereas your and Putin's solution is to allow the boom to fall on everyone outside his closed circle of oligarchs or, in the case of the US, the 99%.

Let's try to be a bit more reasonable and avoid "corruption" talk for a while. What Russian oligarchs do is no different from what Germans or Japanese do: it is called "foreign investment" and is generally considered a good thing, as in more classic economic theory it leads to current account surplus even if oil dries out. At the same time, Russian state is neither extraordinarily dependent on oil nor it does provide excessive social welfare programs; Russia is pretty stingy when it comes to its own money, even if some spending is lavish, as politically they could focus spending on a few areas.

The big issue is that Russia's credit has been cut off, and while Russia's position is not terribly bad, it faces a bank run, similar to what happened on Wall Street in late 2008. Everyone wants their money out, and this is the situation which is very hard to manage from "investment" standpoint, as people who suddenly want dollars essentially create capital outflow.

If something similar happened in US, Krugman would advocate another TARP.

In my current country of residence, (a post-Soviet republic) education was very good in Soviet times because the Soviets put a priority on this. Now education (not to mention health care) is declining in quality. Health care here is abysmal unless you have money to bribe the doctors.
My theory is that when freedom came all of a sudden, there was no institutional or cultural knowledge ("capacity") about how to organize a government based on a free-market economy, with all the regulatory, legislative and judicial infrastructure that are required. Instead, it was everyone for themselves, and this has led to deep-seated corruption and, I suspect, an inadequate tax base for supporting schools and healthcare. In the meantime the ordinary people are asking "why doesn't the government take care of us like in Soviet times?" since that's the only model (besides the corruption) that they have personal experience with.
Unfortunately, there is probably a potential for something similar happening in Cuba. Western Europe, Canada & America have had a lot of practice maintaining free societies: we understand it because we have lived it, both institutionally and as individuals. The question is how to quickly bring the citizens of newly free countries along the same path that it took us a couple of centuries to develop.

I graduated law school in the mid-1980's. It took me 9 months after graduation to get a 'real' job as a full time attorney. Between graduation and my first lawyer job, I lived at my grandparents' home, and worked two part time jobs, and accepted judicial appointments on cases.

I paid for my law school education - partly through student loans, partly by working. It took me six years to pay back my student loans, and the process was very difficult - I lived a very meager lifestyle, but I wanted to be out of debt, so I just did it.

Now it's 28 years since I graduated. Like another commenter, I quit practicing law full time to start and raise a family. I continued dabbling in legal work from time to time, and I also did financial work for a small business.

But, I am glad I went to law school and I'd do it again. In my family I am the first generation born in this country, and the first and only one to become an attorney. Having a law degree and legal experience has opened numerous doors that would not have been open to me otherwise. I have used some aspect my legal training and experience every day in some form, even during the years I was raising a family.

True, law school did not prepare me for the daily grind of legal practice. Law school taught me how to think and analyze like a lawyer though. For me, the college and law school education I earned was invaluable and has served me well throughout my life.

"Putin's policy of rejecting Europe.."
Just wanted to state for the record that (as I seem to recall) Russia at one point did indeed apply for EU membership or association, but were rejected out of hand and met with stony silence by the EU leadership. Of course, Russia sees itself as basically a European country, it is Europe that has a problem with seeing its large next-door and close neighbor as basically an enemy that needs to be contained. Just looking at the map and its history.

Russia's problems include a need to import capital to grow the economy. Whether Putin is in office or not, the need to import capital will remain. China was built on imported capital, a trend that continues today. Scaring away investors with invasions of neighboring countries will not create capital inflows.

Of course a clean system, with enforceable intellectual property laws and the rule of law generally, is also necessary. Political courts do not cut the mustard. Russia must clean up the court system and get politics and corruption out of the courthouse.

Enforceable property laws are also required. Who is going to invest a billion dollars, or a trillion dollars, if the business might be stolen tomorrow?

Openness, of course, Glasnost, transparency, honest corporate governance, independent boards of directors, all the basics that we know in the West. Are these attributes of the West things that would harm Russia or would they help Russia?

Peter the Great founded St. Petersburg as a window on the West, a window that he saw as necessary to prevent isolation and too great distance between Russia and Europe. Russia must recognize, as Peter the Great did, that Russia is part of Europe and there can be no progress unless there is no isolation.

Economic integration with Europe is as necessary today for Russia as it was in the year 1703. Putin's policy of the rejection of Europe is the opposite of Peter the Great's policy of openness to Europe.

Hi Tina,

I don't think we're looking for "some sort of malignant motivation" in the Clintons, and sure, they may do a lot of good with their Foundation and their various projects. If you parse the Clinton Foundation's 990 2012 tax return, you'll see that of $58 million in revenues, only about $8 million went to charitable grants. So about $50 million went for salaries, expenses, travel, etc.

What bothers me is a nagging feeling that they have reversed Jack Kennedy's admonition. In Clinton parlance, this reads "Ask not what you can do for your country, ask what your country can do for you." I can't think of any significant achievements of Bill's years as President.

Our country has done a lot for the Clintons. They have been anointed King and Queen of the Democratic Party and become very wealthy by exploiting their contacts and public image. Who wouldn't enjoy this role? The glamour, the travel, publicity, and social recognition.

I have the feeling with the Clintons, and particularly with Hilary, that if I got to know them better they would impress me as shallow, a little fake, and slightly sleazy. Hilary stood by Bill during all his philandering and through the Lewinsky affair, probably because she enjoyed the perks of being First Lady. If Bill Clinton can cheat so easily on his wife, why did the nation trust him? Even slightly sleazy politicians can do some good, just as a broken clock is right twice a day.

Elizabeth Warren is the real deal. I hope she runs.

Susan, your life sounds a lot like mine! I'm totally stressed out and sleep-deprived through Christmas, and as usual, right now I am just trying to survive the last few days of school, when the kids (even in a high school) have completely tuned out and are wild. And I don't feel any nostalgia or longing for the time when my kid was little because he has just gotten more and more awesome and wonderful with each passing year and is now one of my closest and dearest friends! I'm not a little kid person, though, so that helps! :-)

I never felt weepy at Christmas when my children were young, even though I was usually stressed and sleep deprived. The Christmas program was always my responsibility when my kids were young--they were in my class for four years each--so no time for nostalgia, just relief each time we'd all pulled it off once more. Then it was over, and school was out, and we could concentrate on our family's holiday, Our tree was never up before that Thursday before Christmas.

I guess I have a hard time with nostalgia for my kids' pasts in general. I'm happy to remember their good times as youngsters, but they became more enjoyable the older they got. Each stage has been better than the one before, and they are more who they are to become with each passing year.

Last night I went to the Christmas program (yes, they still call it that) at the tiny public elementary school they attended, where I taught for 30 years. It was great, and most everyone seemed genuinely happy to be there.
